forecast.review: Both forecasters present the same core evidence I relied on: White House confirmation, inclusion on official participant lists, visible Canadian security preparations, and strong historical base rates. They also articulate clear up/down signals that match my priors. The only incremental considerations they add are (1) explicit mention of NOTAMs/airlift/motorcade movements as late-stage confirmation signals and (2) wildfire/airspace disruption as a small tail risk specific to Western Canada in June. These are good nuances but fall within the tail risks I already accounted for. I find their reasoning sound and consistent; nothing materially shifts the balance of probabilities at this time.
forecast.rationale:
Time to resolution: ~12 days until the June 15–17 summit window. Status quo outcome: Yes, given official confirmation, participant lists, and security posture on the ground.

Path to No: Low-probability shocks such as an acute presidential health issue, a domestic/national security crisis requiring Trump to remain in Washington, a specific credible threat to the venue, or travel-disrupting events (severe weather, aviation issues, or significant wildfire-driven airspace problems) that cannot be mitigated with contingency plans.

Path to Yes: Standard execution—Air Force One departs as scheduled; motorcade and security movements proceed; bilateral meetings occur on-site. The logistics and diplomatic choreography are already in place, and the base rate for sitting U.S. presidents attending in-person G7s is extremely high.

Update: The added considerations (NOTAMs/airlift as confirming signals; wildfire risk as a tail) refine but do not shift my estimate. I will move up on release of detailed WH travel guidance and confirmation of wheels-up/arrival; I would move down only on credible reports of illness, crisis, or security/airspace disruptions affecting the venue. Maintaining my prior forecast.
